repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Third Urban Development  (First
            Phase) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; and both
            Bank and Borrower performances are satisfactory. Identified
            as lessons gleaned from the project are the following: 1)
            Continuity is key to long-term development impact. 2) There
            is nothing "simplified" about doing APL as phase I
            is subject to an ICR and phase II goes through similar
            preparation procedures as any regular SIL. In addition, in
            countries such as Guinea which are in low-case scenario and
            have therefore a very small IDA allocation, there is no
            guarantee to move to phase 2 even when the trigger
            indicators have been met. 3) Public-private partnership
            (involving small and medium enterprises and the public
            sector) improves efficiency in delivering municipal
            services: The first lesson from phase I shows that
            concessioning out the collection of household waste to SMEs
            is an efficient and sustainable solution for African cities.
            It works, it reduces costs, it allows to improve the
            environment and public health, creates jobs and promotes
            entrepreneurship and the population is willing to pay for a
            service rendered. The second lesson is that it works because
            a set of enabling measures is in place. 4) The key to
            success was the introduction of municipal audits which for
            the first time provided baseline information on the spatial,
            organizational and financial attributes of Guinean
            municipalities and helped shape municipal programs which
            were not politically based but instead based on priority
            needs set in local realities and expressed at the local
            level. 5) Capacity building works better if it is integrated
            in a contractual arrangement and linked to investments than
            if it is a free-standing component. 6) Street addressing has
            proved instrumental to achieving successful project
            outcomes. It was essential in determining solid waste
            collection zones, supporting the programming of secondary
            streets rehabilitation, and has helped to provide strong
            baseline information on cities. 7) Counterpart funding
            availability is strongly linked to a fully owned, well
            justified, and enforceable local commitment. 8) Clear
            implementation arrangements are essential ingredients for success.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Urban Development Project aims
            to a) improve the living conditions of Conakry's urban
            population through the provision of basic priority services;
            and b) create an enabling environment for sustained
            programming, financing, and management of priority
            investments and services in major urban centers of the
            country. The project has three components. 1) Improvement to
            priority infrastructure and services in Conakry includes a)
            solid waste management, which will increase the level of
            garbage collection and limit the impact of waste production;
            b) neighborhood upgrading, which will support rehabilitation
            and maintenance operations on Conakry's secondary
            roads; c) primary road network, which will improve traffic
            at critical blockage points at Conakry. 2) Assistance to
            secondary cities will support the decentralization process
            by helping mayors to better plan for the need of their
            communes. 3) Institutional strengthening will provide
            support to operational units and improved financing of
            priority services, such as solid waste management and
            secondary road maintenance. It will also finance community
            outreach programs related to waste management.
